title: Mission accomplished: Gerrit Cole delivers one last gem for Astros in pivotal Game 5
text:
CLOSE SportsPulse: Game 5 was setting up to be a series defining game and then the Nationals received devastating news from their ace pitcher and the Astros capitalized. As Trysta Krick details, Washington is brink while the Astros are one game away from a classic comeback. USA TODAY

WASHINGTON – Gerrit Cole’s “legacy” as a Houston Astro is a tricky – and probably useless – concept to peg. A free agent after this season, during which he produced a Cy Young-caliber effort, Cole will likely move to greener pastures, giving him just two years in Houston.

Yet if Sunday night was it for Cole as an Astro, and the 110th pitch he fired in Game 5 of the World Series is the last he’ll fling on their behalf, know this much: His Houston mission was very much accomplished.

Overcoming a shaky Game 1 start that broke a 19-game winning streak that dated to May, Cole seized command of this Fall Classic on the Astros’ behalf, pitching them to within a game of another championship with seven dominant innings.

He struck out nine Washington Nationals in seven innings and kept them at arm’s length all night, summoning 100-mph fastballs all the way through his final inning and owning this crucial 7-1 victory that, for the first time, puts the Astros in command of this World Series.

They take a 3-2 lead back to Houston, with fellow Cy Young hopeful Justin Verlander battling Stephen Strasburg in Tuesday’s Game 6. Zack Greinke lurks in Game 7, with a possible assist from Cole out of the bullpen.

After that? Cole becomes a free agent, and with Verlander and Greinke already set to pull more than $20 million in over each of the next two seasons, the open market will provide Cole a ransom Houston likely cannot match.

UMPIRES: Despite iffy calls, Nationals should blame for Game 5 loss

TRUMP'S NIGHT OUT: Washington's baseball fans were ready for POTUS

Once a Pirate and now an Astro, Cole almost certainly will spend the bulk of his career in whichever city makes him the most desirable offer, be it Anaheim or Los Angeles or New York or any franchise that recognizes the wisdom of hiring a 326-strikeout guy just hitting his stride at age 29.

But these two years in Houston? To the Astros, they feel a lot longer than they look on his stat line.

“I feel like he’s been here forever,” says Astros center fielder George Springer, whose ninth-inning two-run provided the final margin. “The way he gets along with all of us in the clubhouse, the way he came in and bought into us as a team, how our team likes to play the game. He’s extremely fun in the clubhouse.

“I honestly feel like he’s been here for five, six years.”

Cole struck out nine in the Game 5 win. (Photo: Patrick Smith, Getty Images)

The feeling’s understandable. Cole has a staggering 40-12 record in Houston, including playoffs, and his October run this year will never be forgotten, and venerated should they win one more game.

He’s posted a 1.72 ERA in his 36 ⅔ innings, striking out 47 and winning four of his five starts - including a surprise do-or-die game in the AL Division Series against Tampa Bay. He tipped the AL Championship Series in the Astros’ favor by winning Game 3 at Yankee Stadium, and when Houston wrapped that up in six games, the pennant-winning glee was perhaps exceeded by the knowledge Cole would start Game 1 of the World Series.

And then Cole went out and lost for the first time since May, his slider deserting him, then-20-year-old Juan Soto victimizing him for a homer and two-run double, and the 107-win Astros saw six months of handiwork undone.

Sunday, he snuffed out any trouble when it arose.

That man Soto got him again, hitting a seventh-inning home run for Washington’s lone run, but it was his leadoff single in the second that really created trouble. Howie Kendrick followed with a near-gapper that put runners at the corners with nobody out.

No matter. Cole blew a 98-mph fastball past Zimmerman to set up a beautiful sweeping curveball that he flailed at for the first out. Cole then jumped ahead of Victor Robles 0-2 before inducing an inning-ending double play.

That preserved a 2-0 Houston lead that slowly grew on the strength of two-run homers, slow drips that made toppling Cole feel all the less likely.

It’s kind of what happens when he pitches.

“All year, the guy’s been absolutely phenomenal,” says reliever Joe Smith, who worked a scoreless eighth inning after Cole was lifted. “He didn’t bring his A-plus stuff Game 1, but we had a pretty good feeling he was going to come out and do pretty damn close to what he did tonight.”

Smith preceded Cole as an Astro by just a few weeks, signing as a free agent in December 2017; Houston stole Cole from Pittsburgh in January.

“When I signed with the Astros, I was so excited – a team coming off a World Series, had so many guys coming back. I was already pumped,” says Smith. “And then when you see Gerrit Cole’s name dropped, it was just like, ‘Hohhhhh, this is real. Here we go.’

“To watch him come into his own over here the last two years has been so much fun, man. The guy keeps getting better. I love that. I told Will Harris, we’re sitting there in like the fourth inning and I’m like, ‘Man, I love watching this guy pitch.’ He’s so much fun, especially when he’s on your team.”

That joy may be reserved for a different cast in 2020, a group that may look longingly at a championship ring Cole earned in 2019. The Astros are still 27 outs from making that reality – “they’re going to be the 27 hardest outs we’ve had all season,” says Smith – but they can thank Cole for giving them two shots at one win.

Even if that was his last contribution.

“It's been a blast since I've been here,” Cole said before Game 5.

The feeling is definitely mutual, and now Cole and the Astros aim for the ultimate potential parting gift.
description: In what will likely be his final start with the Houston Astros, Gerrit Cole bounced back from a shaky outing in Game 1 to deliver in Game 5.
